Subterrain is a top-down open world survival game set in an underground city on Mars that is currently available through Steam Early Access. In Subterrain you play as Dr West who has woken up to find himself in the abandoned detention centre of the afore mentioned underground city. You were only recently transferred to Mars after the man behind the city, Jeff Murray, invited you so you could continue to work on a cure for Alzheimer's review. After you find your way out of the detention centre and in to the rest of the city you soon realise the entire station is devoid of human life and now you share the city with a number of strange creatures all trying to kill you. Engrossing survival-horror game which seems like a love letter to Alien Breed: Tower Assault and System Shock 2, and what Doom 3 probably should have been - except from an overhead view.

Grindy research/crafting system that makes you feel like you're working a day job at times.

Sole survivor of a virus outbreak in a colony on Mars...all that stands between you and escape is an army of mutants...
And you have only your bare hands...
And the lights are off...
And all you`re wearing is a thin jumpsuit that barely counts as clothing...
And the heat generators are broken...
And the oxygen generators are broken...
And even if they were working, the reactor to power them is failing...

Find, research, and upgrade a wide range of weapons, armour and equipment to keep you alive and the mutants thoroughly dead as you scavenge for 'stuff' to recycle into useful materials.

The atmosphere and music is suitably creepy, and since you can usually only see what`s in the cone of light from your torch you inevitably get nervous and start waving it around in a manner similar to someone trying to shoo away a wasp, because those grunting and growling mutants sound rreeaallyy close...

At the time of writing the game is still in early access, although the devs intend a full release sometime in January 2016.
The game is fully playable at the moment (out of idle curiosity I tried it on a pc with Windows XP and it seems perfectly happy with it), the devs are active on the Steam forums (and quick to squash any bugs that are reported) and open to constructive criticism and feedback as they add further content and polish what`s already there.
All plus points and promising signs for an early access title. (Yeah, I`ve had my fingers burnt before with games being left in an unfinished state, but I`m satisfied with progress on this one)

There are some bugs crop up, but they tend to be quickly fixed. The level maps are partly random, as they are procedurally generated from various tiles and room types, then slotted together. So there can be a bit of repetition, but as more tiles are added then that should become less noticable.

Early Access Review

As of v0.7.3.4:
Subterrain is a top-down survival game set on underground Mars colony.
Something went terribly wrong, everyone's turned into terrible monsters and your only task is to survive.
To make sure you survive, you need food, water, good suit (since it can be freezing or too hot in some parts of the colony), large backpack for your loot and, of course, a gun.

Subterrain is primarily a game about surviving and only after that about everything else (craft, combat, etc).
That's probably why the survival and exploration aspects feel like the most polished ones, while combat and crafting feel pretty basic (although, since the game is in early access, that might as well change until release).
You'll be spending most of your time going around pretty large open world (that is nonetheless is split into areas with loading screens) of the underground colony looking for useful things and monsters to kill. And you'll die a lot in the process.
I found that the best approach for me was to clean out one of the areas and set up a base there - with crafting and research stations, power generator and some lockers for storage.
Having access to power generator is probably one of the most important things in the game - not only does your battery powers your flashlight, but it's also used by your guns.
You do have an option to use a melee weapon, but in my opinion melee combat is just not very good at the moment - you get staggered a lot, there's no way to evade enemies attacks, so it's just turns into a clicking and endurance test.
Using guns are a bit more fun - you get to run away from attackers while shooting back, but that's about it. As I mentioned earlier - combat is not the strongest point of the game.
After gathering enough things you can craft new gear (including modular pistols), research parts of the monsters you was able to gather, synthesise cure and prepare for your next trip.

No major bugs, issues or crashes were encountered during my playtime.
Game does have some small user experience problems (e.g. ESC doesn't closes all menus, no hotkey to pickup all from container - you need to click, no tooltips for items in hotbar) - but they are insignificant and will most likely be fixed (since it's quite easy to do so).
One of the biggest things for me is the fact that there's no manual save game. I do understand that the game wants to be hardcore"

If that sounds OK - go for it. There's plenty of content and enough stuff to do for hours.

reviewText:
A gritty and realistic, singleplayer Sci-Fi survival horror experience from the top-down perspective. This rogue-like/rogue-lite gem will truly test your ability to adapt and survive, whilst fighting off infected monsters, in an underground base on the inhospitable planet we humans call Mars.

You will need to scavenge for food and water. And when you do eat/drink, you will eventually need to ♥♥♥♥/piss. Yeah that's a thing in this game. But the game doesn't force it upon you every 5 minutes like some games would. In about 5 hours of play I only had to find a toilet once or twice if I recall correctly.

You will also need to scavenge materials for crafting. You can craft weapons, clothing, and better basic gear(oxygen, thermal, power.) to increase your odds against the infected hordes you will no doubt face eventually. Crafting is also used to build the components necessary to repair critical systems like heat, oxygen and power to various areas of the underground base. If the infected creatures don't get you, the infection itself will. Finding or crafting enough anti-infection drugs to keep your blood clean will become a priority.

If the infection don't get ya, the cold just might get ya. You'll need to carry a thermal canister(basically a glorified heat pack) in areas that don't have a working temperature regulator. If you can survive the cold, you'll still need to worry about stocking up on food & water. This game's system for hunger/thirst/temperature/sleep/etc may be the best I've seen yet. These needs don't turn you into a walking baby who needs to be fed and burped every 5 seconds(cough cough, DayZ).. It doesn't feel like you have to watch it every second for fear of passing out or something horrible like that. Instead, it keeps you moving, and searching for supplies, because that's the only way you'll survive more than a day in this cold, dark, and forgotten base on Mars.

There are also elements of tower defense in the game, when you must defend the main power reactor for the entire base from advancing infected hordes. But I have not yet survived long enough to be attacked in this way.

This game includes varying difficulty levels, from a normal mode where you are able to manually save, to permadeath hardcore mode, with no manual saves, where damage taken is greater and survival needs are much less forgiving. There's a difficulty for everyone here.

All in all, if you love survival, zombies, and sci-fi horror, give this game a try! You won't regret it.


I should mention that I have not finished this game, and this recommendation is of a pre-release build. My current playtime at the time of writing this is 9.5 hrs.

A true survival game that doesn't hold your hand through any of it.  Find your own way through as you take on dangerous mutants and scavenge for any parts that may seem useful.  Though this game does have a bit of a learning curve at first, once you learn it, the game becomes fairly addicting.

Here are a few negatives:

I found that farming the materials and constantly going back and forth a bit repititive.  I wish that it was basically all in one place instead of being spread out.  However I understand the need to do this as the enemies respawn and can and will surprise you when you think it is safe.

You have to rummage through every bin and look in every corner because if you don't you could potentially miss something extremely important (like a key to the next area).  I almost stopped playing because I was wandering around for over an hour looking for the key to engineering. Luckily I found it.  There should be an indicator or flash or something telling me that something important is in there.

I played this on 2 separate computers and the game jumps frames at times.  I think it was associated with the materials being created or completed when the pop ups occured.

And here are a few positives:

Just a really good little sci fi survival game.  Reminiscent of System Shock 2 in a lot of ways.

The survival mechanics are well done and lend a sense of urgency and purpose without feeling tedious (so far).  There's a feeling of accomplishment as you get O2 and thermal regulators running in various sectors and get more of the base under control.  The atmosphere is really well done. Overall I'd give it an 8 or 9/10.  The relatively minor issues I have with it:

Some of the maps feel a bit unnecessarily large.  Meaning, 5 floors for an area that doesn't feel like it needs to be that big based on the content in it.

The combat isn't bad but it's pretty basic so far.  I know there is a lot I haven't unlocked so I'm expecting it to get better.

It's still an easy buy at $15 if you like sci-fi nerdery.

Subterrain is an indie horror survival game that has simplistic controls and a few jump scares. I honestly wasn't expecting a game with these types of graphics to actually scare me but it managed to very well. The whole concept of this game is a nice one, there are many zombie games out there but this one tries to be different by being set entirely underground. My impression of the game changed after the intro, when I actually got a chance to dive into the gameplay I was pleasantly surprised. The graphics and gameplay are similar to that of the SAS Zombie Assault series, but of course this is not a tower defense, it tells a nice story where you must learn what happened and how to escape the enemy. You also have to use a little strategy when playing because you must collect food and conserve ammo and not blow it all on one enemy.

There currently seems to be minimal instruction in the tutorial, I found myself basically thrown into the wild with no real clue what to do in the beginning. Also I find that the rate of which you become thirsty is slightly too advanced and can perhaps be slowed down a bit. Also in the tutorial the beginning enemies you face can be difficult, taking away a lot of my health but not as easy to find and use items to regain your health.

However it is still early access and I would recommend this game to those who enjoy similar games in the same genre.

reviewText:
Short ReviewYou know, it would be easy to pass Subterrain off as another boring zombie/survival/crafting game in this endless sea of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ cookie-cutter clones of this now stale genre. Yet across the blackened horizon, Subterrain is that blinking light that demands a closer inspection, and with just a few seconds of your time, you realise that this MAY be the game that rises above the rest.

Subterrain is an engrossing and extremely in-depth experience that will grip you by the balls and won’t let go. As a lone survivor aboard a massive space station you must explore, scavenge for food and materials to ensure your survival, plus research and develop powerful new equipment to aid your struggle against the ever growing infected that aims to devour the entire place, with you included.

A blend of Alien Breed, System Shock 2, Dead Space and Project Zomboid. With LOTS of backtracking required and micromanaging of your base of operations, Subterrain is not a casual game and requires a great deal of patience and perseverance to enjoy. It has a few issues with game balancing and pacing. Yet despite this, it’s extremely enjoyable and fun to play and discover for yourself.

Kiddie Steam reviewer verdict: “day 23. Lvl 4 suit and shotgun. Explored the Casino district with 50% infected rate. Ran through the corridors, grabbed a vital data chip, killed 50 zombies. Nearly made it to the exit, but ran out of oxygen. Suffocated to death. 8/10 would asphyxiate again.”

Long ReviewNote: I’m playing the game on normal difficulty without reading any guides. I suggest you do the same for that fresh virgin experience and sense of discovery.

Graphics and soundGraphics are very good and suit the game perfectly, with a 2D presentation that pays homage to top down titles of yesteryear, yet with a silky smoothness added that lets us know it’s running on modern tech. The game is fairly dark, but the colours and lighting have been used to great effect, contrasting yet subtle enough as to remain faithful to the horror theme portrayed. Newly explored areas appear spooky, with a faint mist and coldness to them, whilst areas you've conquered are bathed in sterile warmth.

The sound is well done but quite minimal: there is no spoken dialogue and only the effects of items, machines, (overly loud) guns and growling monsters play out in the world. The music is a bit too overpowering for my tastes, so I’ve had to turn it down a fair bit. Sadly, there's a lack of ambient noises, so you won’t be greeted by the bleeps of a computer console or a menacing grumble of a dark corridor. Hopefully they can add this in the future as it will greatly add to the already stellar atmosphere.

ExplorationWith 15 main areas to visit (some including multiple levels to explore) you can move freely between them and your main base. There’s plenty to see and discover, however it gets extremely tiresome as you constantly need to go back and forth to replenish supplies. It doesn’t help that the levels themselves are fairly large and randomly generated, some rooms leading to dead ends for logical reasons only a computer would understand. Walking simulator springs to mind.

Still, exploration is fun as you’ll need to power up elevators to ease travel plus install oxygen and thermal regulators to make areas inhabitable. As well as scavenging for food and supplies, you need to look out for keycards and dossiers that point you towards shiny new technology, essential for late game survival.

Key item locations are hinted at in journals you find throughout the game world, not only rewarding you with a sense of discovery, but also giving an incentive to move onwards. Items can still be hard to track down thanks to the massive unwieldy level design, but once you know the placement patterns it does become less tedious.

R & DThe key aspect of the game is improving your equipment and facilities to help fight against the ever evolving infected, and it’s done in a neat way. In order to improve something, you first need to lose your current item in order to research the upgraded version of it (as well as manufacture the original).
This presents a dilemma: do you sacrifice that powerful new weapon you just discovered to research, forcing you to rely on that puny pistol for a real time hour? Or do you hang onto it, hoping you’ll stumble into another copy to sacrifice to the research altar? Not only that, do you have the required facility upgrades and materials in order to construct said item? Subterrain is a game that requires you to think not just about the now, but about the future.

You can also mine your own materials and harvest your own food, each in turn can be broken down for valuable resources to aid production of equipment. You can also recycle obsolete equipment, so now you don’t need that single crate full of lvl1 weapons “just in case.” Recycle that rubbish!

You also need to balance your power output by switching off electricity to unneeded areas, replacing burnt out generators and defending them against invasions with turrets. Neglect your power levels and your generator can overload...

SurvivalWith most survival games, you need to eat, drink and sleep (plus ♥♥♥♥), as well as quell contamination, stem bleeding and repair broken limbs. It’s all done with great restraint, so rest assured you won’t need to eat every 15 minutes or repair a broken leg after an infected so much as farts in your general direction. Now this is a basic needs system other survival games should scrutinise - present but subtle, not eat every x seconds or die".

reviewText:
This game is awesome. Think top-down System Shock 2. Perhaps it's not as creepy or as deep, but it's a very fun survival game.

You have to worry about food, drink, biological needs (think toilet!), tiredness, broken bones, bleeding and your own infection. But that's just the tip of the iceberg. Without spoiling it, the game will do a good job of making you think like you're always on borrowed time, edging you to explore further, do it faster.

Yes, a lot of it is repetitive. Same-y looking corridors can become somewhat boring but the gunplay is fun and killing enemies is satisfying. Surprisingly, for a game of this genre, there isn't THAT much inventory management because of a few storage/production facilities you get.

Oh, did I mention there is a lot of possible research? And production of various things? The tech tree is quite extensive and you always know there's something new to discover as far as items go.

But what's perhaps even better is that the developer really is on top of everything. Since release, there have been very frequent updates, fixes and quality-of-life additions (which means the developer is listening to feedback).

If you like survival games and don't mind a little bit of repetitiveness (and don't require an amazing storyline), this game will keep you coming back for more. Fun!

reviewText:
A fun, if eccentrically translated (two of the player's stats being '♥♥♥♥' and 'dump' respectively) little top down shooter/survival game about being trapped in a rapidly deteriorating colony on Mars with a horde of slavering, ever-evolving mutants. The idea that sets Subterrain apart is that player has to manage all aspects of the colony to keep it running smoothly and survive, since the people who would normally handle those jobs are either a) dead or b) now trying to make you dead.

It's surprisingly engaging, and it's clear that a lot of time and effort has gone into making this an enjoyable core gameplay element and not just a tedious gimmick: Mining for resources and growing medicinal plants is almost fully automated and is as simple as telling the respective parts of the base what to do, leaving the player free to run around fighting and exploring while they faithfully deposit resources in Engineering, ready for refinement in their respective machines, whereupon they can be used to make all manner of murdery implements. Research and construction are similarly automated, meaning you can be crafting yourself a brand-spanking new gun while simultaneously queueing up a fresh batch of veggies to seed or pummeling an enormous mutant spider in the face with a police baton on the other side of the colony. Air and heat are also important, with most of the base being uninhabitable until you repair the filters on the oxygen and temperature control devices for the area - something which then drastically reduces the spread of the infection, at least so long as the area remains powered.

At time of writing, there's only one ending and no real time limit, although you may find yourself getting overwhelmed if you take too long to get it; the mutants become progressively stronger and the reactor is damaged, meaning that without regular replacements your power supply will quickly dwindle away to nothing. Not only that, but if left alone to grow to a sufficient strength, the mutants will attempt a sortie to destroy the generator entirely, leaving you to deal with a catastrophic meltdown and a soon to be very cold, very airless colony.

There are minor niggles, such as the occasionally odd translation, the annoying tendency to make areas dark as midnight even when fully powered, and a few rather juvenile attempts at humour that break the immersion somewhat (a torn-apart corpse amidst a pile of food having left a message that it was 'totally worth it' to be horribly eaten alive in exchange for getting to eat a bag of his favourite snacks, for example) but for the most part they're just that; minor niggles that you can easily overlook in favour of all the things the game does right.
Don't play it if you don't like backtracking through the same areas a lot, though. Seriously. There is an absurd amount of it, especially at first.

Oh, and hoard recyclables that give electric resin like they're made out of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ gold, because you need it for ♥♥♥♥ing everything.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Subterrain seemed really promising: good mars colony horror survival atmosphere, competent crafting/research and polished/responsive UI. But now, after 8 hours of play, I wonder why there are practically no negative reviews up for this. I don't really mind the micro-managing (facility power and maintenance) but after having explored 6 of the 16 something areas now,

- crawling through the samey dark corridors and
- being stuck on the same level of research with the same crappy guns,
- fighting the same enemies and always in the same manner,
- having to flee to HQ every 5 minutes to refill O2 and heat,

I begin missing serious progression of any sort. Ultimately, you have very little influence over research and developpment, since it's all tied in to you finding data chips at the end of the explorable areas to upgrade your 4 R&D-levels. And I already know that exploring the next area for a solid 2+ hours, being subjected to the same rinse and repeat formula listed above, I am only gonna get a pointless upgrade for mining level 2 Ore.

Subterrains basic gameplay and different concepts are really well put together but it commits one of the most egregious crimes against its players: wasting your time.

reviewText:
Subterrain is an excellent example of what a talented dev team can do with a small toolset and a deep understanding of what makes video games fun.

This game pushes all the buttons – survival horror, sci-fi zombies, researching tech, exploring rooms and picking through containers, cutting a hole through the darkness with your flashlight, base-building, and a touch of tower defense.

The graphics are not impressive, nor are they meant to be. This is not a game you play to benchmark your new 3d card, but all that flare is hardly missed due to the complexity and urgency that the game gradually builds over time.

Semi-spoilers:

Expect plenty of tension but no cheap jump-scares, a straightforward gather/research/craft system, a quick and easy inventory interface, and a compelling narrative that unfolds via data logs and soliloquies from the main character. Top-down System Shock? Close.

If any of this sounds interesting, buy it. You’ll like this game.

Looking forward to seeing what PixelLore does next.

reviewText:
Subterrain: Fight zombified people and alien creatures on Mars. Now why does that sound familiar?

In all seriousness though, that is pretty much the only similarity between Subterrain and Doom, minus your reliance on the flashlight if you count Doom 3...

Subterrain is a survival horror game with an empathsis on the survival part: You'll need to maintain your daily needs of food, water, rest and toilet visits, whilst also contending with a space station that's crumbling alongside its former inhabitants. Power to the different places on the station is limited, and that's including your base, so don't leave all the lights on everywhere, because you'll be using every scrapt of electricity to travel and survive.

Luckily, you'll have the basic equipment necessary for surviving soon after you escape your prison cell, including weapons, a power pack, and containers of oxygen and heat for when you delve into the broken station. Run dry on any of these and you'll soon wish you'd planned ahead a little better.

But basic equipment is not going to suffice forever, so you'll have to grab your old tools and destroy them in order to be able to research and improve them. But you can't research more advanced equipment with basic computers, so you'll have to find plans and blueprints to improve your facilities to keep up with the times. And of course, you can't build something from nothing, so do like I do: Pick up every little bit of rubbish you can and recycle them into more useful stuff.

I can go on and on about how this game works, because this is a complex game; probably the most complex survival game I've played in a long time. This means that you'll have to be prepared for some mental gymnastics to keep up with everything that's going on. It's not easy, but if you've got experience with survival games you'll probably be okay.

Frankly, I can't recommend this game enough. It's not for casual players, but it's very rewarding to manage everything you come across. Just be mindful: Most of the levels are randomised, so while that means every game is a new experience, it'll also mean that just because you know where something is now, that doesn't mean you'll know where it is next time. This also applies to the facility upgrades. Consider yourself lucky if you can find improved research and production blueprints early on, because those will likely be the most important facilities you'll have.

With all that said, I'm going to go and put my head in a bucket of water to cool down now. See ya next time!


Edit::
I found the BFG! Well it's called a plasma launcher, but come on! Slow projectile, big explosion on impact, destroys most smaller enemies; it's the BFG!

I also discovered a few things about the maps. It seems that the first level of every district is consistant on every playthrough, including the Station Hub and the facilities, meaning it's not completely randomly generated levels.

Also, while I'm at it: I said before that the facility upgrades were placed randomly across the game? Well, I was half right. The upgrades will be placed on a random level in most cases, but they're consistant in which district they appear. For example, the Lvl 2 Research upgrade will always be located in Viking Lane, though on which level is prone to change.

So my advice to new players? After you've acquainted yourself with the facilities and their uses, find the clues leading you to the Lvl 2 upgrades for each facility before you do anything else. It's just the first of three steps, but they make a big difference. Plus, if you go for the higher level upgrades before your facilities have recieved the basic upgrades first, you'll find them to be pretty much useless.
Also, pick everything up. Weapon parts, cudgels, junk, whatever you can. Trust me, you'll need the materials. And keep an extra close lookout for gems and chemicals/alcohols to get rare(-ish) materials early on. You'll gain more from the facilities when you've upgraded them, but it's a slow process. So again, pick everything up!

reviewText:
I absolutely adore this game.

Pros: Wonderful concept, beautiful gameplay and complexity for it's basic style of top down.

Cons: Not complete. If I had one thing to say about this game, it would be that it needs more stuff, more fun, more variety in enemies, and just more stuff! Not a complaint though, this game is awesome.

I found this game to be a bit confusing at first. Things arnt very clear on what you should be doing or where you need to go, but once you figure things out it's relatively straight forward and alot of fun. The simple version is that you find reports leading you to the location of upgrade chips with clues, to enhance the production center and build the parts you need to repair the shuttle and escape.

There has been whisper of a game mode in which you actually fight to clean out and retake the colony. Personally, I LOVE this idea, and cant wait to see if it's true. I hope so! I would love to see a player solo playing, or even somday, able to team up with a friend or two and take the colony back!

A few ideas I have that I'm intending on writing up more thoroughly and suggesting to the devs.

Of course I want to see a take the colony back mode. This might seem like an endless task, clearing out a colony built for thousands, foot by foot, by yourself? YES! This would take a long time and alot of work and I think is a great idea for a long term version of the game. I think this would be awesome as long as it had a separate save from the main game. This game mode should include a type of limited regenerating salvage system.

I think we need to add some monsters that start fires. The fire would lower the oxygen content of the complex even if an oxygen filter is present. The colonist would have to find a nearby fire control point, fill up his fire extinguisher (assuming it's not already filled) and use it to put out the fire before the oxygen levels would stabilize in that section. I think this would be a fun mechanic to add to the game.

Game needs an assault rifle. Dont get me wrong, shotgun is a blast, and pistol is handy, but the machine gun isnt quite as useful as an assault rifle would be, machines are super handy for turrets, but otherwise not so useful, an assult rifle would be quite handy for first person combat.

On screen minimap of explored areas. I dont know about anyone else, but I do get tired of having to stop and look at the main map to see where I'm going, especially when I'm running low on air or heat and trying to get out of the area. A handy little on screen minmap of the complex would be most useful.

reviewText:
Despite the trope of zombies on Mars, I had really high hopes for this game. So far it doesn't deliver, mostly because it is far too much about inventory management to be enjoyable to me. I find myself crawling through the same dark hallways (can you turn the lights back on?) over and over again to fill or empty my tiny backpack or resupply my oxygen.

I also dislike that the various crafting or research stations are separated by loading screens or animations that serves no purpose. And your research and crafting efforts, which is a very nice system, is hampered not by resources but by software cards. So before I can build a better backpack to loot more efficiently I have to loot more stuff... I'd wish for more interactions with the environment as well, such as building barricades or fixing doors.

The best about the game is the ambience. I like that I have to monitor heat and oxygen when I explore new areas, and the shrill sounds of nearby monsters. But since I sometimes fill that lootbag in less than one room, exploring/looting feels more like a chore than part of the survival.

Also, I don't agree with the save system. Just 1 slot feels like a forced ironman and I would not stomach a restart.

Combat is good enough. More detail would have been nice, but not needed. Overall it's not a bad indie game, if there were more options for finetuning the difficulty and settings (bag size, monster respawn, craft station animations, lights) for non-hardcore-fans I'd give it a solid thumbs up.
